articles.title: Session 0: Overview
articles.description: This session provides a quick overview over the course and a short primer to installing and organizing your R environment.
articles.contents:
Contents
Structure of coding lessons
a. 0: Demo
b. 0: Slides
c. 0: Exercises
d. 0: Solutions

Structure of coding lessons
All of the sessions are structured in the same way, presenting the following materials:
a. A narrated slideshow that demos the content we’re working on
b. The slideshow itself, which allows you to click links, copy code, etc.
c. A set of training exercises, marked as either ‘Homework’ or ‘Classwork’
d. Solutions to the training exercises, which will come online after class

—



a. 0: Demo








b. 0: Slides
You can access the full slideshow used in the 0-Overview narration here.

c. 0: Exercises
Normally, this section would have exercises to be done as either homework or classwork. However, since it’s still early in the semester, I’ll let you get away without homework on this one! 😉

d. 0: Solutions
This section will provide the solutions for homework and classwork exercises. But since there are no exercises, we also don’t have any solutions 😔

articles.title: Session 1: Introduction to R
articles.description: This session provides an introduction to the most basic operations and functions in R.
articles.contents:
Contents
a. 1: Demo
b. 1: Slides
c. 1: Exercises
Homework
Bonus homework 🤩

Classwork

d. 1: Solutions

a. 1: Demo








b. 1: Slides
You can access the full slideshow used in the 1-Introduction narration here.
The dataset called ‘coralreefherbivores.csv’ can be downloaded here.

c. 1: Exercises
Homework
Please complete the following exercises at home after going through the demo above. We will go through the solutions to these exercises in class on Monday Jan 29th
create the following vectors:
4 5 6 4 5 6 4 5 6 4 5 6 4 5 6 4 5 6
a sequence from 2 to 36, repeated three times
the words “bluefish” “redfish” and “whitefish” in this sequence, six times
combine the last two vectors into a new vector

create a vector using  rpois(100, 10) 
determine the frequency of the number 8 in your vector
determine how many numbers in your vector are greater than 10
determine how many numbers in your vector are smaller than 10 but greater than 5

build a matrix that looks like this:

[,1]
[,2]
[,3]
[,4]
[,5]

1
2
3
4

6

9

[4,]

[5,]
17
18
19
20
Bonus homework 🤩
Perform these exercises if you want to treat yourself to some extra work. Note that this is not a required part of the homework assignment
create a sequence of multiples of nines between 0 and 100, repeated ten times
create a vector with random values using  rnorm(1000, 0) , with an explanation of what  rnorm()  does
create a second vector using rnorm, but this time with 10,000 elements, a mean of 50, and a standard deviation of 10
tell me what the following functions tell you about your vectors:  length(), str(), summary(), head(), tail() 
retain only the elements from your previous vector that are greater than the mean but smaller than the 3rd Quantile
Classwork
We will do these exercises in class on Monday, January 29th
create a vector using  rpois(500, 10) 
determine the proportional frequency of numbers that are >15
sort the vector in descending order
take the log of the vector and then determine the mean value
replace every 10th value in the vector with 0, take the log, and calculate the mean. Exclude values that cause the mean to be -Inf

build a matrix that looks like this:

Site
redfish
bluefish
whitefish
yellowfish
S1

turn your matrix into a data.frame and add a column entitled “Location” that contains the following sequence: Texas, Belize, Texas, Belize, Texas
determine the mean number of fish at site S3
determine the difference in the mean number of bluefish and yellowfish across all sites
build the following matrix:
100 rows, 20 columns, filled column-wise with randomly-drawn, normally distributed values with a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 10
determine the value of the second-to-last row in column 5
determine which column has the largest value in the matrix and which column has the greatest deviation from the mean (100)

load in the ‘coralreefherbivores.csv’ dataset and
turn it into a tibble
determine the data classes of each column
compare the snoutlength of the species Chlorurus microrhinos and Zebrasoma velifer

articles.title: Session 2: Entering the tidyverse
articles.description: This session introduces the basic functions in dplyr and other packages within the tidyverse.
articles.contents:
Contents
a. 1: Demo
b. 1: Slides
c. 1: Exercises
Homework
Bonus homework 🤩

Classwork

d. 1: Solutions

a. 1: Demo








b. 1: Slides
You can access the full slideshow used in the 2-Tidyverse narration here.
The dataset called ‘fishtibble.csv’ can be downloaded here.
The dataset called ‘coralreefherbivores.csv’ can be downloaded here.
The dataset called ‘fish_abundance.csv’ can be downloaded here.

c. 1: Exercises
Homework
Please complete the following exercises at home after going through the demo above. We will go through the solutions to these exercises in class on Wednesday Jan 31st
Read in the coralreefherbivores.csv dataset (if you haven’t already done so).

The “coralreefherbivores.csv” dataset contains trait information on 93 species of herbivorous coral reef fishes from the Great Barrier Reef, Australia. The first four columns provide taxonomic information (family, genus, species, and a combined genus + species column called “genspe”). The next column “sl” indicates the standard length of the fish. Then, you have three columns with morphological measurements of body depth, snout length, and eye diameter. Finally, you have two columns that indicate maximum body size (categories from XS to XL) and their schooling behavior.
Using the herbivore dataset, perform the following actions:
Determine the mean standard length and standard deviation for the families Acanthuridae, Labridae, and Siganidae.
Create a variable that combines size and schooling into one column.
Count the number of species in each size class.
Calculate the ratio of snout length to standard length for each species, then determine which genus has the longest mean ratio of snout length to standard length.

Bonus homework 🤩
Perform these exercises if you want to treat yourself to some extra work. Note that this is not a required part of the homework assignment
learn about and apply the following functions:
 unite() 
 separate() 
 drop_na() 

Classwork
We will do these exercises in class on Wednesday, January 31st

The “fish_abundance.csv” dataset contains reef fish abundance information, which was collected by the Reef Life Survey around Lizard Island, Australia. It includes information on the respective survey ID and its metadata (e.g. site, latitude, longitude, date, and depth). It also includes a row for each observed species on a given visual survey, including taxonomic information (family, genus, species, and “genspe”), as well as the number of individuals observed on that survey (‘total’).
Using the fish abundance dataset, perform the following actions:
In the family column, replace all occurrences of Scaridae with Labridae.
Filter the dataset to only retain the families Acanthuridae, Siganidae, Kyphosidae and Labridae.
Calculate the mean abundance of each genus using group_by() and summarize().
Remove the standard length, size, and schooling categories from the “coralreefherbivores.csv” dataset (from the previous exercise).
Calculate the mean body depth, snout length, and eye diameter of each genus using gather(), group_by(), and summarize().
Turn each trait into a column using spread().
Join the coralreefherbivores and fish_abundance datasets in their modified versions, retaining only genera that are present in the coralreefherbivores dataset and using “genus” as the joining variable.
using the joined trait and abundance dataset, apply the  case_when()  function to:
create a new variable that separates genera into high (>=2.0) and low (<2.0) abundance genera

d. 1: Solutions
This section will provide the solutions for homework and classwork exercises.

articles.title: About
articles.contents:
Course synopsis

This course aims to provide students with a holistic understanding of the assembly and functioning of marine communities. Students will learn about existing and emerging theories and concepts in community ecology and gain insight into traditional and modern techniques to study marine communities, from visual censuses to molecular approaches.

The course includes quantitative training and practical components using the software R, designed to foster an understanding of basic statistical concepts in community ecology and their thoughtful implementation. No existing experience in R is required but familiarizing yourself with the software early on may be helpful (see resources below).

The course includes two laboratory sessions to be held on Sat/Sun in February (02/16-02/17) and April (04/27-04/28) during which you will have an opportunity to engage in hands-on research on marine and estuarine communities.

             This is the companion page for
            MNS352/MNS382: Marine Community Ecology,
            taught at the University of Texas at Austin Marine Science
            Institute. The aim of this course is to provide students
            with a holistic understanding of the assembly and
            functioning of ecological communities in the marine
            environment. The course provides an introduction to using R
            for the analyses of ecological communities. All materials
            needed to follow and complete the coding lessons and
            exercises are provided on this page.  🔨This
            website was built in R using the
            distill package. All slideshows were created in
            R using the xaringan package.
            🔨

articles.title: Course instructors
articles.description: A brief introduction to your course instructors
articles.contents:
Simon J. Brandl, PhD
Dr. Brandl is an Assistant Professor in Marine Science at the University of Texas at Austin Marine Science Institute. He maintains a research program that revolves around the causes and consequences of marine community assembly. Dr. Brandl originally developed this course in 2022.

Jordan M. Casey, PhD
Dr. Casey is also an Assistant Professor in Marine Science at the University of Texas at Austin Marine Science Institute. She examines ecological communities and trophic interactions among species using molecular techniques. Dr. Casey refined the course materials in 2023.
